loans.name: George

texts.en: George is an artisan who specializes in wood sculptures and African masks. He would like to invest in a bulk purchase of sese wood and polishing materials. George has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story: "In 1990 I settled in the Akuapim hills to begin training as a carver. By the time I graduated, I had become the artist I always knew I was. Four years of careful training had not been undertaken for common standards. Also, my background knowledge of woodwork helped me. I believe in the strengths and aesthetic values of the woods that I and my colleagues transform into works of art. For good reason, I work out many different forms from these materials – sese wood, cedar wood and tweneboa wood in particular." "I would to thank you for your support. This microcredit will help us to continue producing more of our products thanks to a constant supply of raw materials." Use the link below to view George's wood sculptures and African masks on the NOVICA site: http://www.novica.com/kiva/2329

loans.use: to invest in a bulk purchase of sese wood and polishing materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for additional supplies of chicken and pork meat needed in his business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda previously accessed an 50,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. She also has a food vending business for additional income.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better, because more items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Erlinda dreams that her business will last longer and hopes that her family is always in good condition. She meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of their work every week.  It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay their Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries, and beverages to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for machine maintenance and to buy other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
This is Bernadette, 43, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Nephtali, a seaman and they have children. She manages their household while operating the business. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

Bernadette maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, Bernadette is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products such as shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments and other products needed in her business. 

Bernadette dreams of expanding her business and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week where she can draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies and merchandise products such as shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments and other products

loans.name: Lidia Esperanza

texts.es:
Lidia tiene 52 años de edad, logró estudiar solamente primer grado, ella está casada y su esposo se dedica a la agricultura desde hace unos 7 años, tienes 9 hijos, 5 de ellos viven aún con ella, pero solo cuatro van a la escuela.


Lidia se dedica a los oficios domésticos pero también ayuda a su esposo a la siembra de la milpa, ya por este tiempo ella tiene que ir viendo como hace dinero para comprar los fertilizantes, la semilla y otros gastos que se le generan con la siembra, ya tiene siete años de ayudarle a su esposo. El lugar donde tiene ese terreno le queda 10 minutos de su casa y lo hace caminando.


El préstamo lo necesita para ayudarle a su esposo a comprar los fertilizantes de la siembra, semilla, abono y otros gastos que ella hace para la preparación del terreno antes de la siembra.


Sus sueños son que su hija termine los estudios de la universidad, pues con mucho sacrificio está ayudándole para que logre ser profesional.
texts.en:
Lidia is 52 years old and she was only able to study through the first grade.  She is married and her husband has made a living in agriculture for 7 years.  She has 9 children, 5 of whom still live with her, but only 4 of them go to school.  

Lidia does housework, but she also helps her husband to sow the cornfield.  At this time, she already needs to go about seeing how to make money to buy fertilizer, seeds, and other expenses related to planting time.  She has now been helping her husband for 7 years.  The place where she has land is located 10 minutes for her house and she walks there.  

She needs the loan to help her husband buy fertilizer for planting, seeds, manure, and other expenses that she needs for the preparation of the land for cultivation.

Her dream is for her daughter to finish her university studies, therefore she is making great sacrifices to help her succeed at becoming a professional.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for planting, seeds, and manure

loans.name: María Paz

texts.es:
María tiene 52 años de edad, estudió cuarto grado de nivel académico, ella es madre soltera de 4 hijos, solo uno de ellos está en la escuela, y además de sus hijos María vive con sus padres.


María se dedica a la agricultura, desde que se separó de su esposo se fue a vivir con sus padres, para ir al lugar de trabajo se va a pie y le queda a una distancia de 10 minutos en un horario de 6:00 AM a 11:00 AM


Con el préstamo solicitado comprará 5 sacos de abono para que el cultivo sea muy productivo y sacar muchas ganancias.

Los sueños que tiene es que siempre Dios le de vida para poder seguir ayudándole a su papá a trabajar la tierra para sacar más cultivos y poder aportar el alimento a mi familia y que no les falte nada más en la casa.
texts.en:
Maria is 52 years old. She went to school through the fourth grade. She is the single mother of four children. Only one of them is in school. In addition to her children, Maria lives with her parents.

Maria works in agriculture. She went to live with her parents when she separated from her husband. To go to her place of work, she goes on foot, and it takes her 10 minutes. She works from 6:00 am to 11:00 am.

With the loan she has applied for, she will buy five sacks of compost so that her fields will be more productive and she will get good earnings.

The dreams that she has are that God will always give her life to be able to continue helping her father to work the land in order to obtain more crops and to be able to contribute to the feeding of her family, and that nothing will be lacking in her home.

loans.use: to buy five sacks of compost so that her fields will be more productive and she will have good profits.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda owns and operates a business producing copra (dried coconut meat) to earn a living.  She helps her husband to grow and harvest coconut and to sell copra in town.  With the income generated from her farm, her previous loan used for the copra business was successfully repaid. 

Imelda also sells woven nipa to earn an extra income.  Recently, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase fertilizer, such as manure, to help harvest more produce. 

In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Jeana

texts.en:
Jeana previously accessed a 50,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.  Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory.  The more items displayed at the store the better.  More items to sell will result in better profit.  Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs.  She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Jeana dreams that her business will last longer and hopes that her children will have their own business too.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products for her business.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy raw materials needed in shoe and umbrella repair.  Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and with their personal, household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy raw materials needed in shoe and umbrella repair.  Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children.  She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Elvie dreams to open a new branch and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials needed in shoe and umbrella repair.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel owns and operates a farm, harvesting coconuts to sell. He also receives an honorarium, as barangay councilor serving the community, but he never forgets to operate the farm properly. He successfully repaid his previous loan used for the farm. To make improvements, he took a new loan again to purchase organic fertilizer. He plans to fertilize the entire farm for a greener and bountiful harvest in the next cropping. 

In the future, Manuel wants to send all his children to school until they finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase organic fertilizer

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en: Elsa has been a banana farmer since she got married. With her income, she was able to provide the family and successfully repaid her previous loan used for farming. She find ways to improve her income and with GDMPC partnership, her plans are at hand. She took a new loan recently to purchase fertilizer and replanting materials. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and replanting materials.

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en: Ailyn makes a living by providing motorcycle transportation and rental services to people in her community. Her husband is the one who operates her motor as driver. She has been in this business for two years and earns better income from this. She also work as a contractual employee and she gains an extra income from this. To support their transportation business, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy new tires. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from their activities to improve the quality of life she want to provide for the entire family.

loans.use: to buy new tires

loans.name: Marife

texts.en: Marife helps her husband cultivating their own coconut farm for a living. Aside from this, she also sell grocery goods in her retail store located in their village earning good enough to support their income from farming. She had successfully repaid her previous loan used for farming and able to sustain it. Recently, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy organic fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en: Marilyn has been selling goods in their village to make a living. She also earns an income from her farm, their main source of income and was able to sustain it. Her husband personally cultivating their farm. Some of their revenue was used for additional capital for her retail store. Recently, she took a new loan to buy additional grocery goods to resell. She wishes to utilize her earned profit on her children’s education and well-being.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery goods to resell.

loans.name: Narzullo

texts.ru:
Нарзулло живет в сельской местности далеко от города. Как и у многих жителей сельской местности основным источником дохода в его семье тоже является животноводство и земледелие.  Он женат и у него четверо взрослых детей, которых он приучил с малых лет к труду. Его семья очень трудолюбива.  Старшие дети находятся на заработках в России помогают семье. Обрабатывая небольшой земельный участок и выращивая на убой домашний скот Нарзулло вырасти четверых прекрасных детей. Но с тем как растут дети необходимо расширять и жилье. Для этой цели Нарзулло трудится не покладая рук. Наступила весна но еще не проросли кормовые растения которыми засеян небольшой земельный участок. 
Для приобретения кормов Нарзулло  необходима небольшая сумма  и по совету знакомых он обратился в "Арванд" Он надеется , что  при помощи "Арванд" он сможет решить свою проблему.
texts.en: Narzullo lives in a rural area far from town. As for many rural dwellers, the main source of income for his family is raising livestock and growing farm produce. He is married and has four adult children, in whom he instilled work values from their youth. His family is very hard-working. The older children are now in Russia as migrant workers and help out the family financially. Narzullo was able to bring up four wonderful children thanks to his income from working a small land plot and raising livestock for meat. However, as his children grow, his living quarters need to be expanded as well. This is why Narzullo keeps working tirelessly. Spring has arrived, but the plants intended for animal feed have not yet grown on his land plot. Narzullo needs a modest sum in order to buy animal feed. At his friends' advice, he has reached out to Arvand. He hopes to be able to solve his problem with Arvand's help.

loans.use: to buy cattle feed.

loans.name: Fidel Ángel

texts.es:
Fidel de 56 años de edad estudió segundo grado, está acompañado y su pareja se dedica a los oficios domésticos. 

 Fidel se dedica a la agricultura desde que tenía 14 años de edad, este trabajo se lo enseñó su padre para que en un futuro se pudieran defender, trabaja cultivando café, la finca está cerca de su casa y otra parte las tiene en otro terreno a una distancia de 15 minutos a pie de su casa, y sus hijos se involucran ayudándole en el trabajo.

El préstamo lo necesita para invertir en la siembra de café.

Fidel sueña en poder tener una finca productiva muy grande con mucho café, para poder sacar este producto al extranjero y que las cosechas sean de muy buena manera, y así tener ingresos para que sus hijos se preparen académicamente y sean profesionales
texts.en: Fidel is 56 years old and studied up to the second grade. He's in a couple and his partner is a housewife. Fidel has worked in agriculture since he was 14, learning how from his father so that he could make a living in the future. He works in coffee growing and the plantation is close to home, and he does additional coffee growing on another piece of land that's a 15 minute walk away from his house. His children help him with the work. He needs the loan to invest in coffee growing, and Fidel dreams of having a productive plantation with lots of coffee so that he can export and have good harvests. This would give him the income to provide his kids an education so they can be professionals.

loans.use: To invest in coffee growing.

loans.name: Vanessa May

texts.en:
Vanessa May has been running her piggery for more than seven years and she earns well for the needs of her family. Her loan from GDMPC was used for her piggery, to buy feed and additional piglets to raise.   
She find ways to augment her business, while her husband works as a baker. She wants to expand her business and hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family in the future.

loans.use: to buy  feed and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cement, sand, gravel, and labor for home improvement

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es:
Miguel tiene 63 años de edad, no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar está acompañado y su pareja se dedica a los oficios domésticos, han procreado seis  hijos uno de ellos está en la escuela.

Miguel se dedica a la agricultura desde hace 15 años, esto lo aprendió de su padre que en sus tiempos libres lo llevaba a la milpa para que le ayudara y al mismo tiempo fuera aprendiendo el trabajo de la agricultura, sus hijos le colaboran mucho con la siembra, y hasta le ayuda cuando el maíz ya está para sacarlo, su horario es rotativo a veces es de 6:00 AM a 12:00 MD..

El crédito solicitado lo invertirá en un saco de abono, semilla de maíz, frijol y otros fertilizantes que se necesitan para la siembra y para darle seguimiento a la milpa, él siente que va a mejorar porque tiene pensado sembrar una manzana y media de maíz y frijol.



Sus sueños, deseos y esperanzas es que Dios le de salud, y apoyar a sus hijos en los estudios.
texts.en: Miguel is 63 years of age and did not have the chance to study. He is in a relationship and his partner is a housewife. They have six children, one of whom is in school. Miguel has made a living from farming for 15 years. He learned the trade from his father who would take him to the maize field to assist him in his spare time, where he learned about farming work at the same time. The children help out with planting, and even help when the maize is ready to be harvested. He works rotating shifts, sometimes from 6am to 12 noon. The loan he is requesting will be invested in a bag of fertiliser, maize seed, beans and other fertilisers that are needed for planting and for monitoring the maize field. He feels that things are going to improve as he has thought about planting 2.6 acres of maize and beans. His dreams, wishes and hopes are that God will give him good health and support his children in their studies.

loans.use: to invest in a bag of fertiliser, maize seeds, beans and other fertilisers that are needed for planting

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.ru:
Шарофат 54 года, она замужем и имеет двоих детей. Для того чтобы прокормить семью муж уехал на заработки в Россию. Шарофат положительная женщина , которая не может сидеть сложа руки. Наравне с мужем она тоже зарабатывает на жизнь занимаясь земледелием а также ухаживая за домашним скотом. Дети  Шарофат ещё учатся в школе и она хочет чтобы дети росли и жили в более достойных условиях. Её мечта  , чтобы дети смогли получить хорошее образование.  Получая небольшой доход от  земельного  участка и продавая молоко Шарофат пытается хоть как то  отложить на будущее детей. Вот  и в этом году она надеется  получить хороший урожай и тем самым улучшить  жизненные условия для своей семьи.
  Для приобретения минеральных удобрений она хочет взять кредит и поэтому обратилась в «Арванд» . Шарофат  надеется, что работники "Арванд" выслушают ее  и окажут  помощь предоставив необходимую сумму.
texts.en: Sharofat is 54, married and has two children.  Her husband has left for Russia to find work and send money back home to help feed the family.  Sharofat has a number of good traits, such as an inability to idle the day away.  She works just as hard as her husband does to earn a living, toiling in the fields and taking care of the livestock on her farm.  Sharofat's children are still in grade school; she wants them to have a better quality of life than they have now, and hopes they'll be able to get a good education.  She sets aside what money she can from selling produce and milk for her children's future.  She is counting on a large harvest this year, which will help her improve her family's living conditions.  With this in mind, she's seeking a loan from Arvand to buy mineral fertilizers and seeds.  Sharofat hopes that the people at Arvand will hear her out and grant her the help she needs.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for clean and efficient cooking energy from Liquefied Petroleum Gas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for efficient and affordable clean cooking energy from Liquefied Petroleum Gas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for efficient cooking energy from Liquefied Petroleum Gas

loans.name: Sawe Rahayu Indah Group

texts.en:
The Sawe Rahayu Indah group made their payment on time. All the pigs were healthy and reached their ideal weight. Most of them gave the pigs nutritious feed and vitamins and that kept the pigs away from disease. Now the price for one pig is 1.500.000 IDR and they had an average profit per pig of 300.000 IDR.

Ni Komang had success with her plan to manage pigs for pig barbeque (“Babi Guling” in Bahasa Indonesia). With full support from her husband, Ni Komang enjoyed running the pig business very much and used all the profit for her family's income. Now Ni Komang is trying a new business as a cake maker, selling directly to her customers.

To increase their businesses, the group proposed a new loan. They will use it to purchase piglets and feed, and renovate the cages. Now most of the members of the Sawe Rahayu Indah group have a side job. As a farmer, they also become a crop seller. They will sell to the market. Ni Komang will use her portion of the loan to purchase superior piglets for fattening and to support her new business as a cake maker. Her husband helps to feed the pigs three times per day. They hope all the businesses succeed and bring welfare for their entire families.

loans.use: to purchase superior piglets

loans.name: Arvin

texts.en: Arvin operates a piggery to make a living.  He has been in this field of business for many years and he earns enough to provide his family. Recently, he borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy feeding supplies. In the future, he wants to improve the business to earn more income, which will help to improve the general living situation of the entire family.

loans.use: to buy feeding supplies for his pigs

loans.name: Santos Joel

texts.es:
Santos tiene 31 años de edad, estudió hasta noveno grado, está soltero y vive con sus padres que son los únicos que dependen de él.
 Él se dedica  a la agricultura, desde pequeño aprendió a trabajar en la agricultura pues sus padres a eso se dedicaban, tiene que caminar 15 minutos para llegar al lugar donde cultiva.
El crédito lo necesita para pagar el arrendo del terreno donde trabaja, también comprará abono y fertilizantes y pagara en ocasiones mozos para que le ayuden a trabajar sus cultivos, pues cultiva dos hectáreas de maíz y frijol.
Él planea cultivar en mayores cantidades para así poder obtener mayores ingresos, a él le gusta este trabajo, además piensa mejorar la casa donde vive, y si se casa darle lo necesario a su futura familia.
texts.en:
Santos, 31, studied until 9th grade. He is single and lives with his parents, who are his only dependents. He works as a farmer, a trade that he learned at a young age from his parents who did the same work. He has to walk 15 minutes to get to the land where he works.

The loan will be used to pay rent on the land; it will also buy compost and fertilizers, and pay occasional assistants who help him with the crops, since he grows 3.5 acres of beans and corn. He plans to increase his output so that he can make more money. He likes this type of work. He hopes to improve the house where he lives, and if he marries one day, hopes to be able to provide the necessities to his future family.

loans.use: to pay the rent on the land where he works, as well as to buy compost and fertilizers and occasionally pay assistants who help him with the crops.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of grocery products in her village, which she has been doing for many years. She earns well from this, and she has been able to sustain their living. 

With her generated revenue, her previous loans used for the business were successfully repaid. Recently, she took out a new loan to purchase additional goods to resell at her store in order to improve sales.  In the future, Arlene wants to build a house and complete the education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional goods to resell at her store

loans.name: Manyara Grp Group

texts.en:
Caren, who is a vice-chair of Manyara group, is in her late 50s and has six grown children. She is married. Caren is supporting her family's welfare by managing a general store selling a variety of items (rice, baking flour, maize flour, sugar, cooking oil, airtime, soaps, etc). She has been in this enterprise for three years now and is able to make a small profit each month.

This is her second loan request through Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan, which she has paid back successfully, to restock her shop with more inventories. Caren earned a profit, which she used to pay for her welfare. She dreams of building a house for orphan kids. As a mother, Caren is so in-touch to help street children who don't have a chance to win their dreams.  Caren will use her credit request to replenish her shop with popular products. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "MANYARA GRP", which has three members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish her shop with popular products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and run one Fresh Life Toilet

loans.name: Taman Indah Group

texts.en:
The Taman Indah group had an 11,000,000 IDR loan from MUK. The group paid off the loan on time. With seven members, one member had enough saving and used her capital to continue the business by herself. The group decided to borrow a new loan to increase the business.

Ni Wayan, as the head of the group, sold her three pigs for 3.500.000 IDR and still has one left to sell later. After deducting all the costs, she earned a profit of 1,000,000 IDR. She feels so happy because all of her hard work after five months of maintaining the pigs earned results.

She used the profit she earned for her daily needs and saved for her family's future needs.

The Taman Indah group received their new loan of 9,600,000 IDR. Each member received 1,400,000 IDR. This loan was used to purchase superior piglets and feed. With her loan, Ni Wayan purchased two superior piglets for fattening and used the rest to purchase feed. To reduce the costs, Ni Wayan combines a mixture of feed. She hopes that in the next five months, the progress for pig growth will be fast and she can sell at a high price. Her husband helps her in the business by finding a traditional feed such as banana leaves from his garden. With this business, she hopes she can save and renovate her kitchen.

loans.use: to purchase two superior piglets and feed

loans.name: Naroeun

texts.en:
Naroeun is a 34-year-old married woman and a loving mother of five children. Naroeun resides in a small village in Srei Santhor, where she operates a rice farming business on her own farm. Her husband helps her her manages their farm, planting and harvesting rice to sell and for the family's consumption. Having been in the business for years, Naroeun is able to generate a daily income of USD 5.00 per day.

Thanks to Hattha Kaksekar's new water loan program with a special rate, Naroeun is encouraged to focus on ensuring healthy living conditions, safeguarding her family's health, and protecting the environment. She will use the loan she's applying for to build a hygienic latrine and septic tank to improve her household's sanitation practices for the sake of her family.

loans.use: to build a hygienic latrine and septic tank to improve her household's sanitation practices for the sake of her family.

loans.name: Nella

texts.en:
Nella is married with six children. She operates a fishing business to make a living. Her husband works as a teacher. He has been in this field of business for a year, and she earns more to support her husband's income. 

Recently, she borrowed a loan from GDMPC Microcredit to buy raw ingredients to prepare calamay (a sticky sweet rice delicacy packaged in a coconut shell). In the future, she wants to improve the general living situation of the entire family.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida owns and operates an agriculture business to earn a living. She has been growing and harvesting bananas for six years and earns well for the family. 

She paid back her previous loan, which was used for farm fertilization, successfully. To improve the farm, she took a new loan recently to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and farm weeding maintenance costs.

In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and for farm weeding maintenance costs

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora has one child. She operates a general store to make a living. Aside from this, she also finances a farming business to earn extra income. She has many years experience in running the business. She earns well to support the needs of her child and she is able to sustain the business. 

With her generated revenue, she was able to repay her previous loan used for these activities. Recently, she took a new loan from GDMPC to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. 

She hopes to improve the business to ensure a better source of income for the family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods to resell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma owns and operates a general retail store, selling different kinds of daily use products in her village to earn a living. She has earned a better income due to the previous loan she took out. She successfully repaid the loan. To improve sales, she took a new loan to purchase additional products to sell.

She is hoping to augment and expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jovia

texts.en: Jovia is a 25-year-old married female with two children, one of whom goes to school. She deals in the salon business on a busy street and does farming for additional income. Jovia hopes to expand her business. However, she lacks enough capital, which is her biggest challenge. Jovia is a hardworking woman who is accessing a loan to buy hair weaves to use in her salon.

loans.use: to buy hair weaves to use in her salon.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is a 28-year-old married woman with four children, two of whom go to school. They live in Kasese, Uganda. 

Joy operates a retail business located in her rural area. She hopes to expand but lack of enough capital and constant price fluctuations affect her business. She is accessing a loan to buy soap, millet flour and cassava flour to sell.

loans.use: to buy soap, millet flour and cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 30-year-old married female with six children, of which five go to school. She has been selling cassava flour for four years. She works seven days a week and eleven hours a day. Her business is located on a busy street. She also does farming to earn additional income. 

Betty hopes to expand her business into new markets, educate her children, and buy land in spite of bad weather and defaulters. Betty is a hardworking woman who needs a loan to buy cassava flour to sell.

loans.use: to  buy cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Elsi Griselda

texts.es:
Elsi tiene 34 años de edad, estudió quinto grado actualmente está acompañada, su pareja se dedica a la agricultura, todos sus hijos estudian y le ayudan en el trabajo al padre y  nadie más viven con ellos. 
Ella trabaja como empleada doméstica, tiene tres años de trabajar en el mismo lugar y ella junto con su esposo siempre se han dedicado a la agricultura. 
El crédito lo necesita para pagar el alquiler del terreno, y comprará abono, fertilizantes y también pagará mozos, el crédito le servirá de mucho pues cree que así le dará mejor mantenimiento a los cultivos y obtendrá una mejor cosecha. 
Ella sueña con apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudio para que sean profesionales, también piensa seguir trabajando para que sus hijos no les falte nada.
texts.en:
Elsi is 34 years old and she studied through the 5th grade.  Presently she is accompanied by her husband who makes a living in agriculture.  All of her children are studying and they help their father with his work. No one else lives with them.  She has been working as a housekeeper in the same place for 3 years, and together with her husband she has always made a living in agriculture.

She needs the loan to pay rent on the land and buy manure and fertilizer, and she will also use it to pay for assistants.  The loan will serve her well because she will be able to better maintain her crops and get a better harvest.  She dreams of supporting her children in their studies, and she also intends to keep working so that her children have everything they need.

loans.use: to pay for land rental, buy manure and fertilizer, and also pay assistants

loans.name: Elton

texts.en:
Elton is a strong and hard-working man, who makes a living with his own business - a piggery where he grows pigs that he sells in town.

This loan will be used to buy feeding supplies to improve his business. This will allow Elton to keep his business sustainable in order to continue raising pigs and have a greater variety of meat to satisfy his customers. This loan will result in higher sales and a higher income for Elton.

Elton tells us that his biggest desire is to continue improving his business. By doing this, he will have more financial stability and can enjoy a higher quality of life.

loans.use: to buy feeding supplies.

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en:
Jelly previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, house hold and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Jelly hopes that her business will last longer and dreams that her grandchildren will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Meresi

texts.en:
Meresi is a thirty-nine-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom go to school. 

As a retailer for fourteen years, she sells general merchandise like soap, salt, cooking oil and other things. She also sells fish since it is a major source of additional income. 

Meresi hopes to expand her business, although competition and high license fees are difficulties that she meets. She has asked for a loan to buy fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen is a thirty-five-year-old single woman with four schoolgoing children. They live in Kasese, Uganda. 

She has been selling salt for ten years, this being the main business for people living around Lake Katwe. She now needs a loan to buy more salt to sell. 

Allen hopes to educate her children to university level, and to expand her business despite the challenge of unpredictable weather changes.

loans.use: to buy salt to sell.

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: Rashid is a thirty-seven-year-old married man with four children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He has been dealing in buying and selling bananas for many years. He started the business because there is a lot of demand for food as there is famine in most parts of Uganda. His hardship is high transport costs and his vision is to become a market leader in food distribution. Rashid needs the loan to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.use: to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Sirasi

texts.en: Sirasi is a thirty-nine-year-old married man with seven children who all got to school. They are living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in a retail business for ten years, works six days a week and twelve hours a day. The shop is located in the rural area and he also does farming for additional income. Sirasi hopes to educate his children to higher institutions of learning despite the challenge of limited capital. Sirasi is a hardworking man who intends to use the loan to buy sugar, rice and maize flour to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is a thirty-eight-year-old married  female with eight children of whom five go to school. She has been selling crude salt for sixteen years and works six days a week and twelve hours a day. Her business is located at the lake and she also has a retail shop business as an additional source of income. 

Edna hopes to educate children but her problem is the unpredictable weather changes that affects all salt sellers. She is accessing a loan to buy salt to sell.

loans.use: to buy salt to sell.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
This is Agnes. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing.

Besides the poultry business, Agnes operates a fruit and vegetable business.

She would like to apply for a loan to purchase onions, tomatoes, potatoes and vegetables for resale. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to purchase onions, tomatoes, potatoes and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Nzalambi

texts.en:
Nzalambi is a married woman. She has six school going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

Nzalambi operates a cereal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the loan, she wants to purchase sacks of maize for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize for resale

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en:
Kwekwe is a divorced woman with five children, three in school and two underage. She owns a house that has neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling second hand clothes for both men and women. She cites stiff competition as her major challenge in the business. 

She is requesting for a loan to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She joined Yehu to boast her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Elham

texts.en:
Elham is a 51-year-old widowed mother of two. She has been working in her convenience store since eight years ago to help her beloved husband in making their living, but unfortunately, he passed away leaving her alone struggling for her living.

Elham sells tinned food, fruits, vegetables, sweets and beverages. She is developing and improving her specialized cooked food sector, where she sells  daily paltes that attract a lot of employed single men who live nearby. 

She is applying for her second loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to increase her merchandise with special summer products. 

She is still working hard to develop her catering service company.

loans.use: to increase her merchandise with special summer products.

loans.name: Sobhiya

texts.en:
Sobhiya is a 63-year-old married mother of one child. She works selling women clothes, underwear and Brazilian gold from her house and has done this for thirty years, to support her husband who works as a house painter to provide their living expenses.

Sobhiya is a hard worker, She is acquiring her 12th loan cycle from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to increase her business merchandise with a special summer collection.

She is a borrower in good-standing; her previous loans helped her a lot in diversifying her products and covering most of her family's needs.

She hopes to stay in good health and to be capable of supporting her beloved family.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise with a special summer collection.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina helps her husband cultivate their farm for a living. Her previous loans used for farming have been successfully repaid. She had a better income that brought her to open a retail store in their village. To improve sales, she took a new loan to purchase more grocery goods to sell. She wants and hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en: Maricel, a 27-year-old mother of three, helps her husband operate their own farm for a living. For the past six years of growing and harvesting coconut and other crops, the couple was able to provide for the family. In order to enhance her farm, she borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase organic fertilizer. She hopes that someday, her children will be successful in their career.

loans.use: to purchase organic fertilizer

loans.name: Jurinda

texts.en: Jurinda is raising and selling pigs in town to make a living. She has been doing this for four years, earning well to support her children in sending them to school. Her previous loan used for the pig shelter has successfully been repaid. Recently she received a new loan from GDMPC micro credit . She is hoping to make a better returns from her business from the improvements in which she has invested.

loans.use: to buy feeds

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
This is Belen, 49, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Nelson and is a mother to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Belen operates a school/office supplies business. It is where one can buy school supplies, like pens, bond paper, cartolina and the like, without going to a bookstore. She gets the supplies at wholesale prices and sells them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 600 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy school/office supplies to expand her product inventory.

Belen hopes to have a stall near a school and dreams that her youngest child will finish his studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for school/office supplies to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
This is Helen, 63, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is single and she has a child who is working already. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Helen operates a rental space business. It is rented on a monthly basis. She earns a minimum of 13,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every month.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 25,000 loan. She will be using the loan for the repair and maintenance of her rental space. 

Helen dreams that her business will grow bigger. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the repair and maintenance of her rental space.

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en: Hadijah is a 38-year-old widow with two children, one of whom goes to school. She has been selling crude salt for 10 years and works six days a week and twelve hours a day. Her business is located at the lake and she has a motorcycle transport business as a source of additional income. Hadijah hopes to have a good life and a healthy family. However, weather is a challenge being faced. Hadijah is requesting a loan to buy salt to sell.

loans.use: to buy salt to sell.

loans.name: Mathedius

texts.en: Mathedius is a forty two year old married male with four children and all go to school. He has been selling crude oil for five years working six days a week and twelve hours a day. He also has a monthly salary as additional income. Mathedius hopes to educate children however, bad weather and low salary are challenges being faced. Mathedius is a hardworking man and wants money to buy salt for resale.

loans.use: to buy salt for resale.

loans.name: Nyamvula

texts.en:
Nyamvula is married woman with five children, three school-going children and two adults. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and price fluctuation as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, cooking oil.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is still single with no children. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household consumables.

For the past two years she has operated a clothes selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzo is a married woman and has four school going children which is the reason of her hard work.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

Kadzo operates a cafe business making food like, rice, tea, beans, chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality  major challenge.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a stock of goods: maize flour, wheat flour, rice for the business. She joined Yehu to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of goods like maize flour, wheat flour, rice for the business.

loans.name: Mupa

texts.en:
Mupa is a hardworking and enterprising woman who owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. She is a widowed woman with six children, three in school and three underage.

Mupa sells goat meat to her neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the loan,she wants to purchase more goats for her business. She joined Yehu to boast her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business.

loans.name: Al Tanmiya Group

texts.en:
Leila is the featured borrower of Al Tanmiya group. She got together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to improve their business and develop their living.
Leila is a 54-year-old widowed mother of eight children, who works hard as a farmer specialized in planting, harvesting and selling tobacco for the last ten years. This is ensure she can provide her family with a good income to cover their needs. Her loan will be invested in buying the necessary specialized fertilizer for developing her business through increasing her crop production. Leila is the lady at the center of the picture. As for the other members, Zeinab is the lady standing at the far left, and Aiyda is standing at the right.

loans.use: buying necessary specialized fertilizer for developing her business through increasing her production

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 30 years old. He is married with 1 child. He has been in business for four years. He has successfully repaid all his previous loans.

He currently makes an estimated monthly income of KES 45,000 and would like a loan of KES 90,000 through which he will add stock of printing paper and toner so as to serve his clients.

He will use the anticipated profits to buy another copy machine. In the future he hopes to educate his children to higher levels and have a successful business.

loans.use: to buy printing paper and toner

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan  has been earning from her gardening business for many years. Helping her husband working in their farm is a part of her responsibility. Her previous loan was used for farm inputs was successfully repaid. To prepare for the coming planting season she took a new loan to buy organic fertilizer. She wants to improve the general living of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise.

loans.name: Kaza Mwendo Group

texts.en:
Scolastica is a mother of five schooling kids and is in her late 40s. She is married and for five years now, she made her family's living by running a shop selling fabrics, clothes-making materials and dry food items. She works in her business from 7 am to 10 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This is her fourth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to replenish her shop with fabrics and clothes-making materials. With her previous loans, all of which she paid back successfully, she increased her shop inventories. Scolastica received a profit that she used to build a house, cover school fees and pay home food expenses. She dreams of managing a cereal-milling machine. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "KAZA MWENDO", which has two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish her shop with fabrics and clothes-making materials.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
This is Amelita, 59, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Doroteo, a vendor, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Amelita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Amelita dreams of having a bigger space for her store and hopes that her family is always in good health. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Juma

texts.en: Juma is a forty six year old married male with six children of which four go to school. He used the previous loan to buy popcorn and eggs to sell and has been in retail business for twelve years and works seven days a week plus he has a salary and rentals as additional income. Juma hopes to have a wholesale business, however, his capital is not sufficient. Juma is a hardworking man requesting for a loan to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila previously accessed an 8,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase greater quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, house hold and business expenditures.
 
She would like to apply for another 8,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Leonila dreams that time will come that she will no longer rent and hopes that her grandchildren will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell in her variety store business.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
This is Rowena, 44, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Frankline, an employee, and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Rowena operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Rowena hopes that her store will become a grocery store and dreams of giving her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John was born in Nyeri, a county in Kenya and later relocated to Nairobi, the capital city of Kenya. He resides with his wife and three children. John runs several businesses including water vending. When he first saw a Fresh Life toilet  he was on his way home and was impressed by the standard of cleanliness at the toilet. 

John thought of it as a good business opportunity as the standard of cleanliness would attract users to his facility and the environmental impact of a clean toilet. He seeks a loan to help him purchase and run two Fresh Life Toilets. Money earned from the franchise will be used to repay his loan and expand his venture to spread affordable sanitation to a wider population.

loans.use: To purchase and run two Fresh Life Toilets

loans.name: Yofesi

texts.en: Yofesi is a forty nine year old married male with four children who all go to school. Yofesi operates a bar in the urban area, and he also farms and sells coffee to supplement his income. Yofesi wants money to buy sodas and beers for resale. Yofesi started a business to develop himself by putting up resting gardens around the bar. Yofesi is a hard working man though challenged by customers who don't pay him on time.

loans.use: to buy sodas and beers for resale.

loans.name: Sabohat

texts.en: Sabohat is 40 years old. She is divorced and is raising 3 children by herself. Two of them are adults and one of them is still a child. She is the only provider for her children. Sabohat has been busy sewing and selling the national mattress, ‘kurpacha’. Sabohat sells her products in a local market. She has a lot of customers because her products are high quality. She wants to increase her working capital because there is a great demand for her products in the local market. She is asking for a loan of 1000 USD to buy fabric and cotton for making more ‘kurpachas’. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy fabric and cotton for making more ‘kurpacha’

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.en:
Edgardo has a retail store serving snacks to his customers; he sells assorted food and beverages to generate additional income with the help and support of his wife. Edgardo works hard every day in order to provide an income for the family.

Edgardo requested this loan to buy raw ingredients to prepare street foods to sell. He is aiming to develop his business to increase his profit so that he may continue assisting his family with their needs. He wants to improve the general living situation of the entire family.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients to prepare street food to sell

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Anabel is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her, as she was able to buy more products for her variety store. Her loan helped not just in her business but also in the education of her children. Her income from the business is assisting with their everyday household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs. She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add into her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. Anabel hopes that her business will last longer and dreams of giving her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children, in their personal, house hold and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 27,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Leticia dreams of having more customers and hopes to have a better living. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread, needles and other materials needed in her business

loans.name: Nduku

texts.en:
Nduku is a married woman with five children, only one of whom is in school. The rest of her children are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For the past three years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby.  She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, maize flour and sweets for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, maize flour, and sweets for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing and footwear

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet lives in Kampala. She is single with 3 children, 2 of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She lives in a rented house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

Annet sells fruits and vegetables on a retail basis from the market. She has been in business for the last 7 years and she works seven days a week.  She has requested for a loan of Ugandan Shillings (UGX)  300,000 to buy pineapples, watermelons, tomatoes, cassava and sweet potatoes. Her business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She generates additional income from washing people’s clothes.  

Her goal and aspiration is to buy a delivery van and also to get more capital so she can serve more customers.

loans.use: To buy more pineapple, watermelon, tomatoes, cassava and sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Roldan

texts.en:
Roldan, 60 years of age, is married to a private employee and blessed with five children. 

He has owned and managed a printing press in their village for almost three years, and earns a net income of PHP 18,000 per month. This net income is usually spent on their daily expenses and electricity bills. 

Due to insufficient funds, he would like to take out a loan amounting to PHP 50,000 to purchase tools and equipment for his printing press. He hopes that his business will continue to grow and become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase tools and equipment for his printing press.

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more products for her direct selling business. Her income from this business helps her to pay their everyday household expenditures. She and her husband help each other to provide for their family.

Now she would like to apply for another 35,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics, which are needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store, the better! More items for sale will result in better profit, and the profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. 

Minerva looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. She hopes to expand her business and dreams of having a junk shop. 

She meets with her co-fellowship members* every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay back Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
Saodat has completed higher education and been working as a teacher for over twelve years. She teaches computer studies, which she believes is a great job because the modern world is connected by computer technology. She likes her job and is one of the best teachers because her lessons are very interesting for her pupils. Her broader aim is to develop the education system of Tajikistan. 

Saodat is not married and lives with her parents. They live in a house which is in bad condition. To repair the house, Saodat is requesting a loan of 5,000 Somoni to buy building materials such as cement, wood and paint. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To buy building materials as cement, wood and paint

loans.name: Chheorn

texts.en:
Chheorn is a sixty-two-year-old man. He is married and lives in Thmei village, a remote area in Kampong Cham province. He has four children – one is married and three are single. He has been farming for more than thirty years with the assistance of his wife and children, growing and harvesting rice and other seasonal crops to sell for a living. Thanks to his hard work, Chheorn has been able to cover his daily costs and continually develop his farming business.

In order to help him sustain his business, Chheorn is seeking a loan of KHR 2,000,000 to buy farm supplies such as fertilizers and seeds, and pay for labor. His plan is to continue growing his farm and provide the best to his family. Chheorn really appreciates all the help lenders have offered to him and his family.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies such as fertilizers and seeds and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Rhita

texts.en: Rhita is a twenty-eight-year-old married lady with four children living in Fort Portal Uganda. She deals in the retail shop trade and also makes sweaters to supplement her income. She faces challenges of defaulters. However, she has a vision of buying land. Rhita needs a loan to buy sugar, soap and other items to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar, soap and other items for sell

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has no electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a charcoal selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is the high cost of transportation.

With the loan she is requesting of KES 30,000, she wants to purchase 20 bags of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 20 bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Erifaza

texts.en: Erifaza is a married man living in Kasese with fourteen children, two of whom attend school. He operates a retail shop on a busy street, and also farms coffee and works in building as additional sources of income. Erifaza needs money to buy sugar and salt to sell. He hopes to expand his business to new areas, although he faces challenges of competition and price fluctuations.

loans.use: to buy sugar and salt to sell.

loans.name: Asernal Group

texts.en:
Emelisiana, who is a mother of a baby girl, is in her late twenties. She is single, and for a period of four years, she has made her living by managing a business selling a variety of products. Emelisiana purchases goods from Uganda and resells them to shop owners in Tanzania. These goods are handbags, clothes, shoes and bed sheets. It takes one week to travel and return for selling. Emelisiana works from 8 am to 4 pm per working day and is able to make a good monthly profit.

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is her first loan request which she will use to increase on her business capital. She is applying for 620,000 TZS to be apportioned among Arsenal, her two-member group. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. 

Her ambition is to greatly improve her business and life (own a car and build a house).

loans.use: to increase on her business capital.

loans.name: Rahaf Group

texts.en:
Rabiha is the featured borrower of Rahaf Group. She joined with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to improve and develop their living.

Rabiha is the lady standing at the far right side of the picture. She is a 57-year-old married mother of eight children who has been running her convenience store for four years. Rabiha used to sell olive oil and tobacco from her house, but her increasing family needs gave her a strong push towards developing her business for a better income.

She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise with special summer offers that will attract customers' attention.

As for the other members, Raghda is the lady at the center and Rima is standing at the left side.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with special summer offers that will attract customers' attention.

loans.name: Tursunoy

texts.en: Tursunoy is kind woman from a rural area. She is a repeat client of IMON. Tursunoy is a responsible woman and has a good credit story. She is married and has a child who is little. Tursunoy has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 10 years. She has helped her parents to feed cattle since childhood. Tursunoy has great experience in the animal husbandry business. She is the main provider for the family because her husband is a migrant in Russia. He doesn’t send money regularly. Tursunoy is going to repair her house. She is asking for a loan of 2,000 Somoni to buy paints, cement, etc. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy paints, cement, etc.

loans.name: Heidi

texts.en:
Heidi previously accessed an 25,000 PHP loan that she used for purchasing beauty and hair products needed in her salon. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy beauty and hair products needed in her salon. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Heidi dreams that her salon will be known and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and life every week. This is also where she finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for beauty and hair products needed in her salon.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Zainab cooks fried potatoes and sells to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a sack of potatoes and cooking oil. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a sack of potatoes and cooking oil.

loans.name: Momela Group

texts.en:
Irene is single and for six months now has made her living by managing a charcoal store. She is a charcoal supplier and buys 10-15 sacks of charcoal from the field and resells them to small sellers. It takes three days in the field and 2 to 3 days to resell. Irene is able to make a very good profit each month. 

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is her fourth loan request which she will use to restock both her businesses (genge and charcoal).  She used the previous loans to open her new business, a genge, where she sells fruits and vegetables, and to replenish her charcoal store. Irene has repaid the loan and she used her profit earned to buy a cupboard and covered home food expenses.  Irene dreams of reselling her charcoal upcountry.
 
She will share this loan with her loan group ”MOMELA” which consists of two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock both her businesses (genge and charcoals).

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en: Elsa is running a general store selling grocery goods in their community to earn a living. From four years in this business, she was able to earn enough capital to build a little piggery to earn additional income. She has successfully repaid her previous loan that was used for her store. While improving her piggery business, she took a new loan to buy piglets. Elsa wants to provide her family a better life in the near future.

loans.use: to buy piglets.

loans.name: Mark Ryan

texts.en:
Mark Ryan is 20 years old from Cabanatuan City and is enrolled for a 9 month Microfinance Technology Course. His parents are simple residents in their village who earn enough for their needs. 

He joined ASKI recently and has borrowed a new loan to pay the school tuition fee for the first semester. The loan amount of PHP 40,000 is very helpful to continue his studies. He is thankful to ASKI and Kiva that they help deserving individuals to follow their dreams of success.

loans.use: to pay for his school tuition fee.

loans.name: Ana Esperanza

texts.es:
Ana tiene 46 años de edad, lamentablemente no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar, está acompañada y su pareja se dedica a la agricultura, han procreado cinco hijos,  todos aún viven con ellos y trabajan en la milpa junto con el padre.



Ana se dedica junto con su esposo a la agricultura desde hace 12 años, esto lo aprendió de su hermano que se dedicaba a la agricultura desde antes, ella decidió ayudarle a su esposo con la agricultura ya que la familia iba creciendo y su esposo no daba abasto.

El crédito lo necesita para la agricultura, lo invertirá para comprar abono, semilla para la siembra, y  en la preparación de la tierra.

Ella sueña con lograr  mantener su familia siempre unida, luego luchar siempre cada día contra todas las dificultades que en el camino se le presenten.
texts.en:
Ana is 46 years old. Unfortunately, she didn't have the opportunity to go to school. She is married and her husband works in farming. They have five children. All of them still live with them and work in the fields with their father.  

Ana has worked in farming with her husband for 12 years. She learned from her brother who worked in farming before. She decided to help her husband with the farming since the family was growing and her husband couldn't manage it. 

She needs the loan for the farming. She will invest in buying fertilizer, seeds for planting, and in preparing the soil.

She dreams of being able to always keep her family together, and fighting every day against all of the difficulties that come up along the way.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds for planting, and do soil preparation.

loans.name: Dalia

texts.en:
Dalia is a 30-year-old married mother of three children, who has been working as a gymnastics trainer on her own since February 2013, with five years of experience in this domain.
